description.en: There are four seminars and nine lectures each week for the length of the semester. The course has a final project, either as individual or group participation, that is presented and due at the end of course. Once the students select which project they want to focus on, then individuals and the formed groups would be given various readings related to the project. Additionally, there are four homework assignments will help guide students through the design process of the chosen project. The students are also provided a structure for packaging their final project as a design deliverable. At the end of the course there is a short presentation of each project, which is intended to briefly explain the key aspects of the project and the main takeaways on what was learned from applied theory.
description.et: Kursuse käigus viiakse läbi üks ühisprojekt. Harjutatakse probleemi tuvastamist ja hindamist; semiootilise perspektiivi piiritlemist; asjakohase interdistsiplinaarse välja kaardistamist ja semiootiliste teadmiste ja meetodite rolli määratlemist; lahenduskäigu otsimist, planeerimist ja teostamist; meeskonnatöö planeerimist ja koordineerimist.

objectives.en:
The course objective is to give students first-hand experience for applying semiotics to real-world projects and scenarios. The course utilizes Tartu as a creative city to tap into the potentiality of showing how semiotics can be applied to design thinking and strategic planning in the local environment. Students who want to apply do not need prior skills in semiotics or design, and students enrolled in the semiotics bachelor's and master's programs will see how this course is designed to incorporate theories branching from culture semiotics, biosemiotics and ecosemiotics. However, it should not deter any other students without a background in semiotics to attend this course, much of the mechanics of design and semiotics can be understood as a transdisciplinary approach, which is a unique experience for a wide range of students from various departments to gain insight on the application of semiotics. 

The main theory used to orient the course is around the notion of semiotic components (resources, affordances, competence, and scaffolding). As the students will see, the components are practical, as an apparatus, to examine how meaning-making of an umwelt is embedded and constructed within an environment. Additionally, the semiotic components within an environment serve as a trajective compass to navigate our subjective experience through the paradoxical nature of physical reality and digital reality. Students who attend this course will get a clearer understanding on how semiotic theory relates to real-world problems and scenarios; and although the profession of a "semiotician" is usually framed within academia, the students will leave the course with a valuable semiotic toolkit to vividly see how various professions utilize the interwoven relations of design and semiotics.
objectives.et: Projektipõhise analüüsipraktika eesmärgiks on õppida kasutama semiootika teooriaid ja lähenemisi praktiliste sotsiokultuuriliste olukordade ja protsesside hindamisel, uurimisel, aktuaalsete probleemide määratlemisel, analüüsimisel ja lahenduste leidmisel.

independent_work.et:
Homework 1 - Select final project and form groups, if needed. Put together a short description on what the problem is and how to provide potential solution. All project material provided in moodle.
Homework 2 - Upload in moodle a written text that briefly describes what are the desired and non-desired interactions for the user of the final project chosen, keep in mind how the contextualization of the environment can impact the interactions. 
Homework 3 - Identify any relevant things and objects related to the final project, and list any known semiotic components that resonate with the key stakeholders for project, and upload in moodle.
Homework 4 - List any obstacles, concerns, and unexpected outcomes so we can collectively discuss in the following seminar.
Presentation - Present final design deliverable at the end of the course. Provide a recap on the chosen project, the relevant stakeholders, any processes regarding deliberate acts and intentionality, and list any potential design outcomes related to the project.

grade_preconditions.et: For a positive evaluation to proceed with delivering the final project as a presentation, the student is required to attend at least 50% of all seminars and lectures that will be in-person and must submit all (4) homework assignments before the deadlines.

grade_evaluation.et: A positive evaluation of the final result is based on two criteria: (a) the student's completion of previous attendance and homework requirements; and (b) the group's or individual's capacity to provide a coherent analysis for an identified stakeholder in the final project while constructing the design deliverable using the provided structure.
